body:
Hi @yancz1989 
Could you do this?

1. Download mklml into any of your directory. (wget https://github.com/dmlc/web-data/raw/master/mxnet/mklml-release/mklml_lnx_2017.0.2.20170209.tgz)
2. Extract the file, then you will have a directory named ./mklml_lnx_2017.0.2.20170209
3. export USE_MKLML=1;export MKLROOT={the directory you extracted the mklml)
4. Copy 'libmklml_gnu.so' and 'libmklml_intel.so' into /usr/local/ from the mklml_lnx_2017.0.2.20170209/lib directory
5. Please use the default ./make/config.mk file. and just change USE_MKL2017 and USE_MKL2017_EXPERIMENTAL to 1. 
6. compile again.

Please let me know if this doesn't work.

Thanks.
LGTM, but i'll left to @piiswrong to have another look
please add a description that this pr is used to trigger the build, don't need to merge.

@ptrendx , Thanks for your help. My testing environment is:
* GPU: Titan X (Pascal)
* CPU: Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2630 v4 @ 2.20GHz
* OS: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
* Nvidia Driver: 375.26
* CUDA: 8.0.61
* CUDNN: 5.1.5
* MXNet GitHub hash: [5a7aa20](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/5efd91a71f36fea483e882b0358c8d46b5a7aa20)

And my ResNet50's results are:

| Batch size | Speed |
| ------------- |:-------------:|
| 1 | 183.54 |
| 2 | 273.00 |
| 4 | 386.20 |
| 8 | 452.96 |
| 16 | 506.05 |
| 32 | 513.13 |
| 64 | 482.73 |
| 128 | 481.10 |

Your speed results are increasing much more stable than mine. Now, I guess the problem I met may be caused by my testing environment.

Beside the slight speed drop problem I mentioned above, I also found the speed of a specific batch size(i.e. 32, 64 or 128) may accidentally drop a very large gap during my benchmark experiments. And if I run it again, this speed value may recover to a normal level.

In a word, it seems that my gpu does not works as stable as it should be. I will check about the hardware and try to test my scripts on some other machines later.
This was the failed build: http://ec2-52-25-96-65.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com/blue/organizations/jenkins/mxnet/detail/PR-6469/1/pipeline
would you like to submit a fix?
multi gpu/machine ssd training doesn't scale very well
I have encountered the same problem, may I ask you this solution?
@piiswrong Pull request submitted. Thanks!

Hi @ykim362 
I finished the compilation. One more variable should be set in config.mk is the USE_BLAS = mkl.

But, when I run fcn_xs example, I get the following error from gdb.

Thread 76 "python" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fff1a3fb300 (LWP 30958)]
0x00007fff7a953c29 in mkl_vsl_sub_kernel_l9_sBRngMCG31M1 ()
   from /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/mxnet/libmklml_intel.so

Have you ever seen this problem?

How could you run it? 
When I downloaded experiment data, its directory structure was different from one the script expected. So, I got an error that there is no train.lst file.

the problem wanted to solve:
assume there is a very big weight parameter weight_Z, like 100Wx128 dims. we can only update a part of it each time, such as 4Wx128. 
I have implemented in the local calculation by using reset function. but It seems to change a lot code if I want to do it in a distribution calculation.It is feasible, but just a little not easy to do it.

the problem wanted to solve:
assume there is a very big weight parameter weight_Z, like 100Wx128 dims. we can only update a part of it each time, such as 4Wx128.
I have implemented in the local calculation by using reset function. but It seems to change a lot code if I want to do it in a distribution calculation.It is feasible, but just a little not easy to do it.
R.I.P.

Good discussion but the suggestions are not very obvious to readers. Anyhow, in my case, I managed to solve the problem by issuing the following commands.

make ADD_CFLAGS="/usr/include/opencv2" CC="gcc-4.9" CXX="g++-4.9" -j 4 USE_OPENCV=1 USE_BLAS=openblas USE_CUDA=1 USE_USE_CUDNN=1

Right now I am using ubuntu zesty and by default it installed opencv2. As mentioned by Xiaoming, the cflags path was missing from pkg-config. Also, I can't use gcc-6 or gcc-5 because cuda 8 will complain.
@Soonhwan-Kwon

train only on clean-360 can be bad. I'm training on the whole(train+train_360+train_500) dataset and got results cer 0.362836,0.207333,0.173531,0.156486 on epoch 0,1,2,3 for the test-clean and for the 960 hours of train (sample every 100 batch)0.5152, 0.2408,0.1883,0.1622.And it is slow for now because it doesn't use rnn fused cell or variable length approach, but we are working on for the improvement.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7395166/26518285/7d5f17fc-42e8-11e7-9c39-62b095d3152d.png)
And there is deepspeech.cfg for real use and default.cfg is simplified version just for the limited sample.

@ptrendx , Just did a test in a K80 machine. The speed results are all stable like your results. I think my problem is caused by the new titan x gpu or its power supply.

Thank you for your help.

This is what i did:
import mxnet as mx

source = mx.sym.Variable("data")
a,b,c=source.infer_shape(data=(1, 1,64, 64, 64))
print(b)

net = mx.sym.Deconvolution(source, kernel=(3, 3,3), pad=(0, 0,0), stride=(2,2, 2), num_filter=32,ctx=mx.gpu(0),cudnn_off=False)

net.infer_shape(data=(1, 1,64,64,64))
Looks like the text in these two docs has been basically re-written (and has greatly improved).  PR is no longer applicable.


Hi @lx75249. Thank you for answering and giving me the advice for how to use `Symbol::Load`.
I appreciate it and keep using MxNet!!
This issue was actually solved and the point of this was just a my mistake of giving the path of model files. Sorry for make it confusing.
The issue I mentioned above was actually solved and the point of this was just a my mistake of giving the path of model files. Sorry for make it confusing.
@KeyKy: did you do `make clean`, and then `make`? Also: I should have fix for this by the end of the weekend.
It seems that building check always reports `libdc1394 error: Failed to initialize libdc1394`
No news, but I didn't forget about it.

Now I am running the code on Deep Learning AMI Ubuntu Version. How can I enable cudnn? I changed the config.mk to :
```

 # whether use CUDA during compile
USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag
# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
# USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CuDNN R3 library
USE_CUDNN = 1
```

And then I reinstall the python library as:
`sudo python setup.py install
`
With those changes, I am getting the same error as the above posts when using deconvolution
@qclu Can u still work it correct at mxnet 5.28 latest version?  it just didn't work

When you do forward and backward, the function returns as soon as the operators are pushed to the engine. `update_metric` is the sync point which makes sure the operation is completed. That's why you observed little time spent on forward and backward. Better consult `profiler` for better performance profiling.
Have you tried `pred = out.get_outputs()`? This can give you the prediction for last forward() operation, and you can customize your loss function per data point.

I have run into this issue installing mxnet on Ubuntu whilst trying to follow the instructions [here](http://mxnet.io/get_started/ubuntu_setup.html#quick-installation).

As far as I can tell (and I'm far from an expert) this is to do with an incorrect installation of openCV. To get it working again I needed to:

1. Install openCV following the instructions [here](http://docs.opencv.org/2.4/doc/tutorials/introduction/linux_install/linux_install.html)
2. Update my dynamic library configuration by running `sudo ldconfig`

Thought I would write this down here in case it's of help to someone else, or me in the future.
Done by this function: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/executor/graph_executor.cc#L90
please add tests for legacy ndarray loading
@tqx0808 try vs2015 with proper cuda version 8.0.44
R.I.P.
@jychoi84 I mean the labels of the model. The model predicts a location of an image, I would like t find all labels of the locations. Thanks!
@piiswrong Exactly what I'm looking for, thanks.
just use slice_axis and reshape
Having the same issue here with opencv 3.1. Go back to opencv 2.4 then everything is fine. But I am not sure if this is the problem. I will try to figure it out.

I am able to resolve it by putting these dlls into the system PATH

libgcc_s_seh-1.dll
libgfortran-3.dll
libquadmath-0.dll

OpenBlas depends on it but it is not obvious.

Need to check the dependencies using dumpbin.exe

Kim

@piiswrong HI Junyuan, just have a follow up problem. I think the aggregation function is defined [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/1974be4a345b4b048826652a63fe74960730736c/src/operator/tensor/elemwise_sum.cc#L21), do you know if there are some ways I can output the gradient of each data point in one batch online? Thank you in advance.

@patricianing  http://data.dmlc.ml/models/imagenet/synset.txt

I don't think you can bind on multiple devices? Maybe I'm wrong, but binding an executor from a symbol is the lowest-level execution machinery which asks to allocate memory on a specific device, in which case it wouldn't make sense to bind on multiple devices (that would mean you create multiple executors). 

If you want to spread training out over multiple devices, you should use a higher-level API like Module, or write your own higher-level interface that does the managing using tools like the KVStore.

I am able to output the exact gradients at each backward operator like in [softmax output](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/softmax_output-inl.h#L108) and [cnn v1](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/convolution_v1-inl.h#L180).

But I was hoping there are higher level functions I can output the gradients, like while we are doing element-wise-sum in AggregateGradient function.

I have been digging into this a bit. Here is what's going on as far as I can tell, please correct me if I am wrong. 
`'loss'` eval metric calculates the [sum of the forward pass](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py#L922), however, the SVMOutput symbol doesn't actually calculate loss, instead, [it passes its input on](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/svm_output-inl.h#L66). So the output of SVMOutput `Forward` is the output of the preceding layer.

Wouldn't this lead to an error in the backward pass? The loss would be a sum of the previous layer's outputs rather than a true loss, this would lead to a miscalculation in the gradient?
Or are forward-loss values never actually used, and both gradients and loss are calculated simultaneously during `Backward`? relevant code: [[1](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/svm_output-inl.h#L91-L95), [2](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/9bd0f8915b5f23e407c98086df05246c5905285d/src/operator/svm_output.cc#L10-L49)]

If I get a little clarity on this, I am happy to open a PR that correctly calculates hinge loss.  I am just not sure what happens to the forward output of SVMOutput....

Or is there some optimization with aws that I'm not aware of that allows for the ability to scale easily? Thanks again !

I don't think so (at least as of Apr 14). 

What I was requesting was to be able to save the fitted model object (in its native class) so that it can be re-used in future sessions. A workflow like: 
```r
model <- mx.mlp(data = x, label = y)
save(mode, file = "model.RData"")
q("no")

## new R session
load("model.RData")
predict(model, newdata)
```

Having an export function doesn't really solve that problem. Maybe an intermediate step of 
```r
model <- serialize(model)
```
prior to saving would be a solution.
I couldn't reproduce this issue. Maybe transient? @antinucleon @piiswrong - Is this issue fixed?
please always ask another committee to have a look before merging.
OK. My fault.

@topepo I have added two helper functions. The network symbol and parameters will be saved using `saveRDS`.

I restart the R session after saving, so the external pointer won't work. Can you give some advice on this?

```r
require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.mlp(train.x, train.y, hidden_node=10, out_node=2, out_activation="softmax",
                num.round=20, array.batch.size=15, learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9, 
                eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy)


mx.model.save.RData(model = model, filename = "test.RData")


#### restart the R session

require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

model <- mx.model.load.RData("test.RData")

preds <- predict(model, test.x)
pred.label <- max.col(t(preds)) - 1
table(pred.label, test.y)
```

@indhub Can you give me more information on the **quality bar**?

Thank you!
I suggest we start with image classification, Faster-RCNN and SSD. They are quite important

Hi @jmerkow, 

As long as the backward derivation is correct, we don't need loss in forward pass.

But the current way that mxnet use to calculate loss are lack of some info (like margin defined in SVM layer), which is inconvenient, I think it would be better to calculate loss in forward pass as well.

I have created a pr for hinge loss #6496, negative loss does not make sense, you can use by setting eval_metric = [mx.metric.SVMLoss(), ...]
Let's call it HingeLoss

It got rounded to evenly divide batch_size.
predicts[:98940] would give you the real predictions.
The last ones are padding

what kind of data?
which piece of doc is confusing?

you can simply compare the result from following two expression:
a=np.arange(48).reshape(1,3,4,4)
ret1 = mx.nd.L2Normalization(mx.nd.array(a),mode="channel").asnumpy()
ret2 = a[:,0,:,:]/np.sqrt(np.sum(a[:,0,:,:]**2))
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/606

Having a separate function to save isn't a solution to this issue for two reasons that I can think of:

1. you can't embed the model in some other data structure (such as a list or tibble) and save that data structure
1. having a separate `save` function treats these objects differently than any other. If every model did this, R's api would be horrendous; nobody wants to remember a different save command.  

For case #1, it would preclude someone from doing any ensembling of models (like Bayesian model averaging or bagging) as well as having a [`caret`](https://github.com/topepo/caret/blob/master/models/files/mxnet.R) module. Also, a lot of people are using a [`modelr`-type workflow](https://drsimonj.svbtle.com/k-fold-cross-validation-with-modelr-and-broom).

@topepo I know very little about the ensembling and that's why I need your help.

I just add two helper functions `mx.serialize` and `mx.unserialize`, so the workflow looks like below.

I am not sure if this is what you expected.

```r
require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.mlp(train.x, train.y, hidden_node=10, out_node=2, out_activation="softmax",
                num.round=20, array.batch.size=15, learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9, 
                eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy)

model <- mx.serialize(model)

save(model, file = "test.rds")

q("no")

load("test.rds")

require(mlbench)
require(mxnet)

model <- mx.unserialize(model)

data(Sonar, package = "mlbench")

Sonar[,61] <- as.numeric(Sonar[,61])-1
train.ind <- c(1:50, 100:150)
train.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[train.ind, 1:60])
train.y <- Sonar[train.ind, 61]
test.x <- data.matrix(Sonar[-train.ind, 1:60])
test.y <- Sonar[-train.ind, 61]

preds <- predict(model, test.x)
pred.label <- max.col(t(preds)) - 1
table(pred.label, test.y)
```

If this can help people use `mxnet` inside `caret`, can you also give some suggestions on function names? Is `serialize` OK?
The same problem occurs to me!

`sudo ln -s /dev/null /dev/raw1394`
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/fd43d6880f0599d213dd3dd2d178a975fc9823b9/docker/tool.sh#L67

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/70a0eeb14a508dec47460a0c289ca73eef27d6d7/docs/how_to/cloud.md#build-and-run-mxnet-on-a-gpu-instance

Now that I look, plain old [`serialize`](http://finzi.psych.upenn.edu/R/library/base/html/serialize.html) is already used in base R so `mx.serialize` and `mx.unserialize` would be fine. It would be good to add a `is.serialized` function to do a test beforehand. 

You might want to embed the `mx.unserialize` call inside of `predict` (conditional on the results of `is.serialized`). 

For ensembling, I think that a list of models containing objects from `mx.mlp` would be saved and `lapply` would be used to get each model's prediction, then averaged. I wrote a prototype about a year ago that you can [look at](https://github.com/topepo/caret/blob/master/models/files/avMxnet.R) (see lines 31-41 and 62-66). I'm guessing that the serialization would need to happen inside of the `for` loop when the model is created?

RNN package will be refactored with the NN interface to support imperative+symbolic use.

If you want to merge this in earlier you can put it in a contrib/experimental namespace and add the imperative interface later.

see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/nn for detail

Thank you for the valuable advice.
